title: THX Tuneup Survey feedback disclosure via Google cached content for apps.thx.com
vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
If you use this google dork: ```site:apps.thx.com```, you will notice many of the links no longer work. However, in the cached versions, they contain lots of sensitive user information from users who seemingly filled out a survey, including first and last name, zip code, gender, email, country (and sometimes down to city), and other information about products they own.

Obviously it is of upmost importance to protect user privacy and this does not protect it whatsoever. Even though the pages no longer currently exist, the cached versions are all still readily available just by clicking the small green arrow and clicking "Cached".

## Steps To Reproduce:
1. Search ```site:apps.thx.com``` on Google
2.  Find results within "/THXTuneupSurvey/Feedback/Delete/"
3. Click the small green arrow next to the URL
4. Click "Cached"
5. You will be able to view all of the information listed above.

## Supporting Material/References:
N/A, not going to attach pictures of user's personal information for obvious security purposes.

## Suggested Remediation:
To remediate this, I believe you can contact Google to remove all web caches. Not sure how this happened originally but the current pages do not leak any of this information anymore, they simply give a 404.

## Impact

An attacker can use all of this information to make targeted phishing attacks toward users, or if they are looking for someone's email and they have their name or some detail that the victim listed in their question, they can use this database to get their email and/or other details.
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:

If you use this google dork: site:apps.thx.com, you will notice many of the links no longer work. However, in the cached versions, they contain lots of sensitive user information from users who seemingly filled out a survey, including first and last name, zip code, gender, email, country (and sometimes down to city), and other information about products they own.

Obviously it is of upmost importance to protect user privacy and this does not protect it whatsoever. Even though the pages no longer currently exist, the cached versions are all still readily available just by clicking the small green arrow and clicking "Cached".

Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Search site:apps.thx.com on Google
  2. Find results within "/THXTuneupSurvey/Feedback/Delete/"
  3. Click the small green arrow next to the URL
  4. Click "Cached"
  5. You will be able to view all of the information listed above.

Supporting Material/References:

N/A, not going to attach pictures of user's personal information for obvious security purposes.

Suggested Remediation:

To remediate this, I believe you can contact Google to remove all web caches. Not sure how this happened originally but the current pages do not leak any of this information anymore, they simply give a 404.

Impact

An attacker can use all of this information to make targeted phishing attacks toward users, or if they are looking for someone's email and they have their name or some detail that the victim listed in their question, they can use this database to get their email and/or other details.

structured_scope.asset_identifier: Razer web properties NOT in Group 1 (as listed)

activities.message:
Forgot to add:
 #374007 is a good reference report.

Also to prevent google from ever caching your pages, you can put this in the header:
```<meta name="robots" content="noarchive">```
And you can use [this](https://www.google.com/webmasters/tools/removals?pli=1) tool by Google to request removal of all of these sensitive caches.
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Hi @jackb898,

Thank you for your submission. Your report is currently being reviewed and the HackerOne triage team will get back to you once there is additional information to share.

Kind regards,
@antenna

activities.message:
Hello @jackb898,

Thank you for your submission! We were able to validate your report, and have submitted it to the appropriate remediation team for review. They will let us know the final ruling on this report, and when/if a fix will be implemented. Please note that the status and severity are subject to change.

Regards,
@antenna

The internal team are still working on the issue.

If you recheck your original PoC, you can see that the cached pages are not accessible, yet some information is still disclosed:
> █████████

Best regards,

activities.message: THXTuneupSurvey was removed when this was first reported. Resolving the case.
activities.markdown_message: THXTuneupSurvey was removed when this was first reported. Resolving the case.

activities.message: @justinimmanuel Actually @antenna’s conclusion above is still correct; while the cached pages are no longer accessible, email addresses are still leaked in the description.
activities.markdown_message: @justinimmanuel Actually @antenna’s conclusion above is still correct; while the cached pages are no longer accessible, email addresses are still leaked in the description.

activities.message:
Thank you for helping Razer secure its customers' information.  Our target to award bounties is 15 days from triage and we know it has been much longer than that.  Please accept our apologies for the very lengthy delay in payout. 

As HackerOne should have informed you, we are currently pausing our program from accepting new submissions.  We will be addressing our bounty payout process prior to resuming as we understand that the current lag times are unsatisfactory.

As a general reminder (not specific to this report), please note that bounty amounts are not based solely on the Severity rating of the vulnerability; rewards are based on overall risk and impact.  Other factors include the system tested and the quantity of customer data at risk.  This is mentioned in our bounty policy.
activities.markdown_message:

As HackerOne should have informed you, we are currently pausing our program from accepting new submissions. We will be addressing our bounty payout process prior to resuming as we understand that the current lag times are unsatisfactory.

As a general reminder (not specific to this report), please note that bounty amounts are not based solely on the Severity rating of the vulnerability; rewards are based on overall risk and impact. Other factors include the system tested and the quantity of customer data at risk. This is mentioned in our bounty policy.
